body_html:
As @asimshankar said, this is CentOS 4.4, which was released about 10 years ago apparently. Linux used to have SystemV formatted binaries, I think.

According to this, if you use od you should be able to see which format you have.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Executable_and_Linkable_Format

The only route is to build from source, but you need gcc-4.x with C++11 support for that. You might be able to cross-compile.

The only route is to build from source, but you need gcc-4.x with C++11 support for that. You might be able to cross-compile.
body:
As @asimshankar said, this is CentOS 4.4, which was released about 10 years ago apparently. Linux used to have SystemV formatted binaries, I think.

According to this, if you use `od` you should be able to see which format you have.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Executable_and_Linkable_Format

The only route is to build from source, but you need `gcc-4.x` with `C++11` support for that. You might be able to cross-compile.
